page.title: 18Interviews I
page.content: Pupils from Sutton Benger School interviewed the village's oldest inhabitant, Mr Ernest Sharps, age 95, about his early memories. He spent his childhood in Seagry, which was part of the same parish as Sutton Benger before the motorway split the area in 1970. He remembers, at the age of 10, watching the Bath passenger coach changing horses in Sutton Benger High Street. It had liveried coachmen who sounded post horns. At the turn of the century he tolled the church bell at the local memorial service on Queen Victoria's death. As a 14 year old he went to work on a farm in Minety, earning 14s 6d per week. He returned to Sutton Benger to farm in 1951, but lost some of his land when the M4 motorway was built.
